children.subject: Plus, 16B has more extension of Linear Algebra and differential equations’ contents covering more engineering-oriented fields, so it wouldn’t totally be a waste of time even if you’ve already taken 54.

<md>I agree with this. I took 54 with Nadler before 16B, and even the (large) parts of 16B that were repeats of 54 content didn't _feel_ like they were repeats. Even though I got a high grade in 54, 16B seemed to give a fresh and different perspective, and in many cases it made me realize that I might not have understood 54 as well as I thought I did.</md>

16B’s Linear Algebra part covered some branched topics that may not be emphasized by 54. Since physics 89 is a course with unstable quality and mathematical depth, 54 sometimes bears on a load of physical math methods. 16B would focus on some EE-related math topics that 54 browsed through but not directly related to physics.

<md>(I know this is off-topic but now I am intrigued.) What do you mean by "unstable quality and mathematical depth"? Physics 89, unlike 54/16B, has multivariable as a prereq, and [the physics department website strongly urges](https://physics.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-degree/the-major-and-minor-program) physics students to take 89 rather than any other linear algebra class. Surely there must be a reason for this?

This is of interest to me because I am literally signed up to take 89 in addition to 54, 16B, and 110, and I wonder if you know how redundant this is.</md>

Well, a senior student on Astro wiki mentioned that the physics 89 he took didn’t prepare him well for his later studies in astrophysics and he had to relearn Linear Algebra with 54 and 110.
However, this is changing these days. I think today’s physics 89 should be better. I didn’t take 89, but my opinion after browsing the syllabus is that the essence of physics 89 is its physics backgrounds elaboration accompanying math teaching, and its emphasis on a tensor-based Linear Algebra.
In conclusion, what I’ve mentioned about “unstable quality” should be a historical problem and may not be applicable now. If that caused any problem or misunderstanding, apologies in advance.

@Beaker Physics 89 still has unstable quality and mathematical depth, as the curriculum is not exactly set in stone. The content that physics 89 teaches can vary largely from semester to semester. For example, when I took it with Ganor in fall 2020, the class really focused on solving differential equations, and we basically got none of the topics that physics 89 typically advertises for, which is tensors and infinite dimensional basis. Furthermore, physics 89 might not give you a great linear algebra foundation. People complain that EECS 16A teaches linear algebra too quickly by going through it in 4 weeks. My physics 89 class managed to go through everything in 2 weeks. To get the most "authentic" physics 89 experience, I would recommend taking it with Austin Hedeman, since I think he is the guy that developed the course in the first place.
👍Great summary! That doesn’t only fits the description on Astro wiki but fits my friends’ experience of Hedeman’s 89 as well!
what is astro wiki? i felt like 16a covered linalg well fwiw lol

16A does cover linear alg decently, and I haven’t said that it’s insufficient, did I? It’s just the organization of 16A kind of different from 54 and other linear alg courses since it has circuits and intro to basic machine learning applicational codes to cover, making the taste slightly different.
As the name suggests, Astro wiki is a place for Astro major/intended students, just think it as a supplemental website for Astro 101 piazza and a tiny resource site.

Haven’t taken 149 before, but IMO, embedded systems involve physical world interactions. And these processes don’t only require math of Linear Algebra, but circuits-related knowledge as well. 
I guess at least you should take 16B as a prereq.

history.content: Prerequisites are not enforced so you could self study the needed part from 16b.

children.subject: 16A circuits is enough for the class, but 16B would be nice.

history.content:
I just wanted to confirm that the website says 16A+B are the pre-reqs for EECS 149, if we took math 54, would it satisfy this pre-req? 
The course website is https://www2.eecs.berkeley.edu/Courses/EECS149/ .  
Thank you in advance.
history.subject: eecs 149 pre-req
